abstract: In search of more users, Google takes the “beta” label off of Chrome.
snippet: In search of more users, Google takes the “beta” label off of Chrome.
lead_paragraph: Google made a splash when it announced its new Web browser, Chrome, in September. Like many of Google’s new products, Chrome first appeared in a beta, or test, version. That limited its appeal, as corporate users in particular tend to shy away from using software that is still in test mode. Perhaps as a result, Chrome’s share of the Web browser market  is less than 1 percent. In the new browser wars, that’s a rounding error compared with Internet Explorer’s nearly 70 percent market share.
